001
002package com.commercetools.docs.meta;
003
004/**
005 * {@include.toc}
006 * <h2 id="compatibility-module">SDK v1 compatibility module</h2>
007 *
008 * <p>The SDK provides a compatibility module. This module e.g. allows the usage of the SDKv2 client
009 * with in conjunction with all the commands of the SDKv1. For more details please see {@link Compatibility}</p>
010 *
011 * <h2 id="client-configuration-and-creation">Client Configuration and Creation</h2>
012 *
013 * <p>From the 1.x we substitute the <strong>SphereClientFactory</strong> class with the <strong>ApiRootBuilder</strong> class in the 2.x.</p>
014 *
015 * <p>The benefit is that after the <strong>ApiRootBuilder</strong> has been defined, it's easy to create the requests directly from it.
016 * There are example below that can clarify the behaviour.</p>
017 *
018 * <p>
019 *     <b>v1</b>
020 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#configuration()}
021 *     <b>v2</b>
022 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#configuration()}
023 * </p>
024 *
025 * <h2 id="timout-setting">Timeout Setting</h2>
026 *
027 * <p>In both versions is the <strong>executeBlocking()</strong> method that sets the timeout.</p>
028 *
029 * <p>
030 *     <b>v1</b>
031 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#timeoutSettings()}
032 *     <b>v2</b>
033 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#timeoutSettings()}
034 * </p>
035 *
036 * <h2 id="headers">Headers</h2>
037 *
038 * <p>To set headers, in the 1.x there is the <strong>HttpRequest</strong> class and in the 2.x the <strong>ApiHttpRequest</strong> class.</p>
039 *
040 * <p>The main difference, as you can see the example below, is that the <strong>ApiHttpRequest</strong> can be directly instantiated and it
041 * can be directly set the type of method (GET or POST), the URI, the headers and the body.</p>
042 *
043 * <p>
044 *     <b>v1</b>
045 *     <pre>There is no way to set the header directly in the request</pre>
046 *     <b>v2</b>
047 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#headers()}
048 * </p>
049 *
050 * <h2 id="retry">Retry</h2>
051 *
052 * <p>In the examples below there is a huge difference about the *Retry* for the v1 and v2.</p>
053 *
054 * <p>As can be seen, in the v1, it has to be define piece by piece: the retry rules, then the
055 * <strong>SphereClient</strong> and then the request in this case <strong>PagedQueryResult</strong>.</p>
056 *
057 * <p>On the contrary in the v2, the setup of the request can be built directly during the client creation,
058 * so we are going to have the <strong>ByProjectKeyRequestBuilder</strong> built including the setting of the Retry
059 * through the <strong>RetryMiddleware</strong> and as a plus, like in this case, it is possible to set up other
060 * parameters to our request like the logger <strong>InternalLoggerFactory</strong>. After that, we will have our
061 * request <strong>CategoryPagedQueryResponse</strong>.</p>
062 *
063 * <p>
064 *     <b>v1</b>
065 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#retry()}
066 *     <b>v2</b>
067 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#retry()}
068 * </p>
069 *
070 * <h2 id="draft-builder">Draft Builder</h2>
071 *
072 * <p>About the *DraftBuilder* the main difference is that in the 2.x there are not inheritances for the *DraftBuilder* classes,
073 * but there are no so much differences in the behaviour.</p>
074 *
075 * <p>
076 *     <b>v1</b>
077 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#draftBuilder()}
078 *     <b>v2</b>
079 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#draftBuilder()}
080 * </p>
081 *
082 * <h2 id="create-command">Create Command</h2>
083 *
084 * <p>In the v2 there are not dedicated classes for the <strong>Create Command</strong>, but there are builders (you can see better in the
085 * <a href="#update-command">Update Command</a>. It means that to have a request it needs to have a draft to build which has to be passed
086 * into the <strong>post()</strong> method.</p>
087 *
088 * <p>
089 *     <b>v1</b>
090 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#createCommand()}
091 *     <b>v2</b>
092 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#createCommand()}
093 * </p>
094 *
095 * <h2 id="create-from-json">Create From Json</h2>
096 *
097 * <p>The main difference in this case is that we replaced the {@link io.sphere.sdk.json.SphereJsonUtils} class with the {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.utils.json.JsonUtils} class.</p>
098 *
099 * <p>
100 *     <b>v1</b>
101 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#fromJson()}
102 *     <b>v2</b>
103 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#fromJson()}
104 * </p>
105 *
106 * <h2 id="update-command">Update Command</h2>
107 *
108 * <p>Like the <a href="#create-command">Create Command</a>, there are not dedicated classes for the *Update Command*, but the use of
109 * the <strong>UpdateBuilder</strong> to create the type of update action to apply in the <strong>post</strong> method is substantial
110 * to build the update action.</p>
111 *
112 * <p>Here the differences:</p>
113 *
114 * <p>
115 *     <b>v1</b>
116 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#updateCommand()}
117 *     <b>v2</b>
118 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#updateCommand()}
119 * </p>
120 *
121 * <h2 id="query-getbyid">Query - GetById</h2>
122 *
123 * <p>In case of query by Id, the v2 is not so different from the previous cases, except that it uses the <strong>get</strong>
124 * method before other ways to filter our request.</p>
125 *
126 * <p>
127 *     <b>v1</b>
128 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#queryById()}
129 *     <b>v2</b>
130 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#queryById()}
131 * </p>
132 *
133 * <h2 id="query">Query</h2>
134 *
135 * <p>To continue the previous case, to build complex query we use <strong>{@link com.commercetools.api.models.ResourcePagedQueryResponse}
136 * (in the v1 is {@link io.sphere.sdk.queries.PagedQueryResult})</strong> which is meant to apply limit, count, total, offset, and result
137 * to our query. And the structure as the example before is to use <strong>get</strong> before other ways to filter our request.</p>
138 *
139 * <p>
140 *     <b>v1</b>
141 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV1#query()}
142 *     <b>v2</b>
143 *     {@include.example example.MigrationV2#query()}
144 * </p>
145 */
146public class Migration {
147}
